DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Partial Closure of operations, Ammonia Removed from Site

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Olam uses anhydrous ammonia for freezing vegetable products.  Ammonia is the only hazardous chemical used at this facility that is subject to the CalARP program or federal RMP requirements.



This facility recognizes the hazards associated with the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  As a reflection of our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations, we submit this plan to address the hazards inherent with the use of ammonia.  Our program addresses safety precautions regarding the handling and operation of this covered system as well as proper training for those who operate and maintain the system.  The company training policy requires that all employees be properly trained for a job position before assignment to that job.



Our accidental release prevention program is clearly defined by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program for this facility and the Program 3 Prevention Program of the CalARP Program.  The prevention program follows industry-recommended standards for preventing unnecessary human exposures and reducing the threat to the health of our employees as well as to members of the community and the surrounding area.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these chemicals, the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility and its processes, and the training that we provide our personnel.  The prevention program is updated as required.



Our Emergency Action Plan (EAP) details the actions this facility will take in the event of an emergency.  The Plan includes procedures for notification of the local emergency responders and safe evacuation of personnel on-site.  A primary Emergency Coordinator (EC) has been assigned to implement the required actions and a secondary Emergency Coordinator has been assigned as a backup to the primary EC.  This Plan is current and updated as required by law and conforms to the requirements for an

Emergency Action Plan as per 29 CFR 1910.38 and 8 CCR 3220.



This facility has also coordinated with the local emergency responders and maintains close relations to ensure that the responders are familiar with the system and with the general safety and accidental release program at our plant.



It is the policy of this facility to devote the time, energy, and capital toward maintaining prevention and response programs appropriate to the inherent dangers with the use of hazardous chemicals.



 

THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



A.  The Stationary Source



The Olam facility is located in the agriculturally productive Central Valley in Modesto, California.  The plant is situated at about 90 feet above sea level at the southern border of the city limits of Modesto along Whitmore Avenue.  The land south of Whitmore Avenue (City of Ceres) has been developed for residential use.  The Union Pacific Railroad tracks separate the facility on the west from light industrial businesses.  The Post facility borders the northern property line of Olam and shares the same gated entrance on Whitmore Avenue.  Approximately 40 acres of agricultural land lie to the east, which in turn, are bordered by Morgan Road on the eastern border.



The Olam facility, operated since 1958, processes vegetables into a variety of bulk dehydrated and/or frozen products.  The facility operates three shifts throughout the year with some variance depending upon crop availability.  Raw vegetables are trucked to the site and unloaded prior to washing in the wet processing building. Once the vegetables have been washed, they are processed, dehydrated and/or frozen, and packaged.  The frozen vegetables may be re-blended for specific customers, which involves the use of ammonia refrigeration.



Plant security is provided by a guard located at the main gate entrance to the facility. The security guard provides emergency response support under the direction of the Emergency Coordin

ator.  The entire plant is enclosed by a chain-link fence, except at the main gate, where trucks and personnel enter and exit as directed by the plant security guard.  Electronic identification pass cards are required for vehicle entrance through the main gate to enter the plant.  Fingerprint recognition is used within the plant as a clock-in device.  The ammonia refrigeration system room entrance is protected by a key code locking device.  Process and office buildings are fire-sprinklered and connected to a centralized automated alarm system  The alarm has Voice Evacuation capability and can offer instructions pertinent to an event. 



B.  Regulated Substance Handled



The Olam Spices and Vegetables, Inc. Modesto California facility operates one (1) anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.  The system is configured as a hybrid one-stage / two-stage mechanical refrigeration system that utilizes a recirculated liquid evaporator feed for product freezing.  The closed loop system uses both liquid pumped overfeed and flooded systems.



The system operates or is in pumpdown mode 24 hours a day each day of the year.  During operation, the system is attended by trained personnel.  On weekends, holidays, and other downtime periods, the system is in automatic pumpdown mode and does not require operators.  A supervisory alarm system monitors the ammonia sensors via the programmable logic controller (PLC) and notifies the Maintenance Manager immediately of any upset conditions.

The current capacity of the system is 797 TR, designed to operate at a low-stage saturated suction temperature of -50 ?F SST.  High stage saturated suction temperature is +10 ?F with a saturated discharge temperature of +90 ?F.  The current charge of the system is 18,700 lbs. refrigerant grade anhydrous ammonia.



The condensers, suction accumulators, air pre-cooler coils, surge drums, make-up air unit, and the liquid transfer unit are located on the Engine Room roof, while the compressors, intercoo

nts include the following:



QTY          DESCRIPTION

5    High Stage Compressors (HSC)

1    Swing Compressor (SWC1)

3    Low Stage Compressors (LSC)

3    Evaporative Condensers (EC)

2    High Pressure Receivers (HPR)

2    Suction Accumulators (SA)

1    Intercooler (IC)

1    Liquid Transfer Unit (LTU)

2    Liquid Recirculator Packages (LRP)

1    Air Pre-cooler Coil (EV10) with Surge Drum (SD1)

1    Make-up Air Unit (MAU1) with Surge Drum (SD2)

2    Belt Freezers (FF)

4    Evaporator Pre-Cooler Coils - direct expansion (EV)

5    Ammonia pumps (AP)

3    Oil Pots (OP)



 

System Operation



EVAPORATIVE CONDENSERS (EC1 - EC3)



The Evaporative Condensers drain high pressure liquid (HPL) to the High Pressure Receivers (HPR1 & HPR2), which then supply liquid to the recirculator packages (via the intercooler), air pre-cooler, or for the screw compressor liquid injection cooling (LIC).  Each of these loads has control devices, which automatically throttle liquid flow as required.



The roof-mounted evaporative condensers receive high-pressure vapor from the main discharge header common to the high stage refrigeration compressors.  The evaporative condensers reject the heat of the system (heat of compression, the refrigeration loads and connected motors) to the atmosphere by evaporation of water and airflow.  The high-pressure vapor condenses to high-pressure liquid.  The ammonia is condensed at a design pressure of 165.9 psig, which results in a high-pressure liquid condition of +90 ?F @ 165.9 psig.  The optimal operating parameter target is 125 psig.

EC1 and EC2 are identical condensers, each with a heat of rejection (THR) of 5513 MBh, while the rated heat of rejection for condenser EC3 is 4410 MBh (217 tons) THR.  The design conditions for the EC1 and EC2 condensers are +90 ?F condensing, +76 ?F wet bulb.  The design conditions for the EC3 condenser is +90 ?F condensing, +78 ?F wet bulb.



HIGH PRESSURE RECEIVERS (HPR1 [East] and HPR2 [West])



The combined high-pressure receivers are also d to

contain the system ammonia charge, if necessary.  The liquid capacity of each receiver is 9,284 lbs., or a total of 18,568 lbs. for both receivers  The high-pressure receivers are designed for 250 psig working pressure in accordance with the storage duty.  The high-pressure receivers operate at a design condition of +90 ?F @ 165.9 psig with an operating parameter target range of 125 psig and a maximum of 190 psig.



An equalizer line between the condenser discharge and the High Pressure Receivers ensures that equal pressure is maintained between the two points to ensure proper liquid draining.



INTERCOOLER (IC1)



The intercooler receives intermediate pressure vapor from the booster discharge header common to the low stage refrigeration compressors and the pre-cooler receiver.  As this vapor bubbles through 0 ?F liquid in the intercooler, it is cooled and desuperheated.  The intercooler was designed to desuperheat vapor to design conditions of 0 ?F @ 15 psig.



The second purpose of the intercooler is to subcool high-pressure liquid from the high-pressure receiver before it goes to the liquid recirculator package.  The intercooler was designed to subcool liquid from +90 ?F @ 165.9 psig to +10 ?F @ 23.8 psig.



LIQUID RECIRCULATOR PACKAGES



(LRP1, AP1 (East), AP2 (West))

(LRP2, AP3 (East), AP4 (West))



The plant system has two (2) liquid recirculator packages, which are each designed to operate at -50 ?F @ 14.3" Hg.  LRP1 and LRP2 use a centrifugal pumps to deliver low-pressure liquid to the belt freezers FF1 and FF2 at an overfeed rate of about 4:1.



The recirculator vessels are d for the ammonia in the respective belt freezer, plus the charge in the associated supply and return lines. 



Liquid ammonia is pumped from each LRP by two (2) centrifugal ammonia pumps.  The pumped liquid is sent to the evaporators and part of the liquid (approximately 25%) expands and flashes to vapor at saturation temperature as the pressure is reduced through the respecti

ve expansion valves and the low-pressure liquid absorbs heat from the space.  The resulting mixture of liquid and vapor flows back to the recirculator packages. 



SUCTION ACCUMULATORS (SA1 [South], SA2 [North], LTU)



The low-pressure stage has two suction accumulators.  Both of the suction accumulators are designed to operate at -50 ?F @ 14.3" Hg.  A liquid transfer unit (LTU) provides a means of transferring excess ammonia liquid in the accumulators back into either HPR1 and HPR2 via pump AP5 into the condenser drain (CD) line.



Once the LTU liquid level rises to a setpoint, a level sensor opens the three-way solenoid valve, allowing hot gas from the high side discharge of the compressors to drain the liquid in the LTU to the High Pressure Receivers (HPR1 & HPR2).   As the liquid level in the LTU drops, the three-way valve changes position and transfers ammonia vapor back to the Suction Accumulators (SA1 & SA2).



Low stage suction (LSS) vapor from LRP1 and LRP2 is discharged into the suction accumulators.  The suction accumulator sizing allows for adequate separation of the liquid and vapor.  The low stage compressors take this vapor from the suction accumulator and the cycle continues.



 

AIR PRE-COOLERS 



The evaporator coils transfer heat from the air and/or water into the liquid ammonia, which causes the ammonia liquid to change to a low-pressure vapor.



Pre-cooler No. 1 (SD1, EV1)



The intermediate stage has a flooded air pre-cooler, which has a dedicated receiver (surge drum) designed to operate at +30 ?F @ 45 psig and an evaporator designed to operate at +10 ?F.



The liquid from the surge drum (SD1) gravity flows into its evaporator (EV1) and part of the liquid (approximately 10%) flashes to vapor.  The resulting mixture of liquid and vapor returns to the surge drum by the thermosiphon principle.  The surge drum sizing allows for adequate separation of the liquid and vapor.  The high stage compressors take this vapor via the intercooler, w

hich acts as a suction accumulator to protect the high stage compressors from liquid slugging.



The air pre-cooler evaporator (EV1) has serpentine coils with ammonia in the coils and air blowing over the coils.  The air pre-cooler is defrosted with hot gas and supplemented with sprayed water.  The cool air is used to pre-cool vegetables before they enter belt freezer FF1.  Note:  EV1 was designated as EV10 prior to the freezer expansion project in 2008.



Pre-cooler No. 2 (EV2, EV3, EV4, EV5)



A second pre-cooling system consists of four (4) coil sections for maintaining a room temperature of 35 ?F for vegetables prior to entering the second belt freezer FF2.  The coils include one (1) coil rated at 863.3 KBh THR, one (1) Stage 2 coil rated at 122.0 KBh THR, and two (2) after-cooler coils rated at 108.1 KBh THR.  The first coil is defrosted by air, while the other three coils are defrosted with hot gas.



The first pre-cooler coil and the Stage 2 pre-cooler coil use 30 ?F liquid ammonia, while the after-cooler coils use 18 ?F liquid ammonia.



Packaging Room (SD2, MAU1)



Packaging Room cooling is supplied by a flooded make-up air unit, which has a dedicated receiver (surge drum SD2) designed to operate at 25 ?F @ 39 psig and an evaporator designed to operate at +10 ?F.  The design temperature for the area to be served is 45 ?F.  Cooling is provided to the Packaging Room, the Hammermill, and the Blending Room.



 

BELT FREEZERS (FF1 & FF2) 



The Frigo belt freezers or IQF (FF1 and FF2) are comprised of two serpentine coils for transferring heat from the freezer space to the recirculated liquid ammonia as air blows over the coils.  The freezer coils are periodically defrosted using hot gas with water spray capabilities.



HIGH STAGE COMPRESSORS (HSC1 - HSC5)



The five (5) high stage refrigeration compressors are a combination of reciprocating compressors (HSC1 and HSC5) and screw compressors (HSC2, HSC3, and HSC4).  The reciprocating compressors have w

ater-cooled oil coolers.  The oil cooling for the screw compressors is accomplished by direct liquid ammonia injection (LIC) into the compressor.  The purpose of the compressors is to create a suction that will pull the low-pressure vapor from the intercooler and the air pre-cooler and to compress the vapor to a high temperature and high pressure.  The system high stage suction level is set at 0 ?F @ 15.7 psig.  The design conditions for the high stage compressors are +10 ?F SST, 90 ?F condensing.  The high stage compressors provide hot gas defrost (HGD) via the high side discharge (HSD) lines for pre-coolers and the freezers.



SWING COMPRESSOR (SWC1)



This single-stage, 400 hp screw compressor was added to the system in June 1997 to accommodate the needs of the new Frigo freezer (FF1).  The compressor is economized with ammonia vapor via a 2" line tapped into the intercooler dry suction line.  The purpose of the economized compressor is to control suction pressure.  Low-pressure vapor for the compressor comes from the booster suction line from the suction accumulator.  Oil cooling for the compressor is by direct liquid ammonia injection into the compressor.  The compressor suction level is set at -45 ?F @ 11.7" Hg.  The design conditions for the single stage compressor are -20 ?F SST, +90 ?F condensing.  This compressor could be run in AUTO mode in place of LSC1 if LSC1 is down for maintenance service or repair.



LOW STAGE COMPRESSORS (LSC1 - LSC3)



The three (3) low stage (booster) refrigeration compressors are screw compressors.  LSC1 was formerly designated LSC6 until the 2008 freezer expansion project.  New compressors LSC2 and LSC3 were also added to the system in 2008.  The screw compressors use direct liquid ammonia injection (LIC) for oil cooling.  



The purpose of the compressors is to create a suction, which will pull the low-pressure vapor from the low stage evaporators (belt freezers) through the liquid recirculator packages and suction accumu

lators as described below.  The system low stage (booster) suction level is set at -45 ?F @ 11.7" Hg.   The design conditions for the low stage compressors are -50 ?F SST, 10 ?F condensing.



An Autopurger periodically removes noncondensibles from the system.  The Ammonia Diffusion Tank is maintained full of water to absorb a system overpressure release from the vessel pressure relief valves.  Emergency E-stop switches are located at the entrances to the Engine Room for emergency shutdown.  Ammonia sensors in the Engine Room and production areas trigger audible/visual notifications.



OIL POTS (OP1, OP2, OP4)



The oil pots provide a means of safely removing accumulated refrigerant oil from the system.  Oil travels with liquid ammonia but does not mix well.  Where the liquid tends to accumulate (such as in a vessel), the oil will separate and fall to the bottom.  The oil pot function is to collect this oil and remove it from the system using a strict valving procedure (see Oil Draining SOP).



AMMONIA DIFFUSION SYSTEMS (AD & ADP; ADT)



Ammonia Diffuser (AD) and Ammonia Diffusion Panel (ADP)



The purpose of the ammonia diffuser (AD) and ammonia diffusion panel (ADP) is to manually control a release of ammonia from the refrigeration system in the event of an emergency.  By opening valves in the diffusion panel, ammonia will be mixed and absorbed in water in the ammonia diffuser.  The resulting water and ammonia mixture will be drained to the sewer from the diffuser.



Ammonia Diffusion Tank



The ammonia diffusion tank (ADT) has been d to accommodate one pound of ammonia per gallon of water.  The tank capacity is approximately 30,000 gallons and its  is 12'-3" diameter and 34'-0" overall height.  Safety relief valves (SRV) at system vessels are piped into a collective discharge piping system, which ultimately discharges to the ammonia diffusion tank in the event of an SRV release.  In the event of a release to the ADT, the ammonia-water solution will be disp

osed as required by law



VENTILATION SYSTEMS



There are two ventilation systems for the refrigeration system.  One system serves the Engine Room and the second system provides ventilation for the remote pump package (LRP1) room.



The Engine Room ventilation system consists of two (2) rooftop upblast ventilators, each with a nominal air flow capacity of 30,000 cfm.  One fan is normally energized at all times for continuous ventilation.  The second Engine Room fan will operate once a 150 ppm ammonia vapor concentration (50% NIOSH IDLH: Immediately Dangerous to Life and Health) is detected and then signaled to start by the PLC.  The solenoid King Valve and hot gas solenoid valves will also close at 150 ppm.  The fans can also be operated manually using the key switch outside the Engine Room door at the breezeway.  The fans can also be operated when the E-stop is activated.



The Engine Room fans are equipped with explosion-proof motors and spark-resistant blades to satisfy National Electric Code requirements for a non-hazardous environment.  At 40,000 ppm ammonia vapor (25% LFL: Lower Flammability Limit), all other electrical equipment, not rated for Class I, Group D, Division 1 under the National Electric Code, must be de-energized.  At 1,000 ppm, an Engine Room detector will shut down the electrical equipment, well below the LFL.



The remote pump package (LRP1) room exhaust fan is set for continuous operation.



DETECTION SYSTEM



The ammonia vapor detection system consists of nine (9) sensors total:



Qty.    Type    Location    Equipment ID

1    Infrared    Engine Room    AS01

2    Electrochemical    Engine Room    AS02

AS03

1    Solid State    Relief vent line to ADT    AS04

1    Electrochemical    Recirculator LRP1 Room    AS05

1    Electrochemical    Frigo FF1 Packaging Room    AS06

1    Electrochemical    Frigo FF2 Packaging Room    FF2_A02

1    Electrochemical    Recirculator LRP2 Room    LRP2_AD1

1    Electrochemical    Make Up Air Unit    MAU1_AD1

 

Audible/visual alarms will be triggered by sensor detection at 50

ppm (PEL: Permissible Exposure Limit) vapor levels in the Engine Room.  



SYSTEM MANAGEMENT AND OPERATORS



The operation staff consists of the Maintenance Manager and Refrigeration Operator/Mechanics. The operation and maintenance staff consists of one (1) Boiler-Compressor Operator (BCO) per shift at a minimum.



Staff is responsible for the operation and some of the maintenance of the refrigeration system, as well as the daily monitoring.  Most service and repair activities are contracted to a qualified refrigeration contractor.



THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



This facility complies with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Key prevention steps taken by this facility to maintain safety are outlined in the PSM Program.  These include the description of all system and equipment information, process hazard analysis, operator training, contractor qualification, operating procedures, pre-startup safety review, hot work permitting, management of change, mechanical integrity, incident investigation, compliance audits, and emergency response.



Those who operate, maintain, or supervise the system will be trained to understand the principles of ammonia refrigeration and ammonia properties, an understanding of the process equipment and proper operating and maintenance procedures, recognition of abnormal conditions and the steps to correct deviations, and emergency shutdown procedures as appropriate to the level of involvement each employee will have with the process.  Contractors that perform maintenance or that design changes to the system will be qualified by the facility based upon their experience and safety record before being selected to provide such services.



The general safety program includes hazardous communication, forklift operation, first aid, emergency response, confined space entries provisions, line break p

ermits, and additional programs as necessary to maintain a safe operation.



THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



On March 20, 2011, a release incident occurred that was detected and reported as required.  It was estimated that 6,783 lbs. anhydrous ammonia were released after an extensive investigation was conducted.  The release occurred as a result of actions by a contractor welder, who punctured ammonia-containing equipment.  As a result of the investigation, contractor safety procedures were enhanced and the contractor was disqualified from performing any further work at the facility.



THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Employees are trained to understand the requirements of the Emergency Action Plan.  The Emergency Action Plan includes release notification for emergency responders and the procedures for evacuation.  The Emergency Coordinator implements the response in coordination with the local emergency responders (i.e. the fire department).  It is the policy and practice to conduct evacuation drills regularly.



This facility is included in the community emergency response plan and has coordinated response activities with the local fire department.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



A five-year update and revalidation Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed as required in May 2013.  The 2013 PHA team developed a list of recommendations to improve safety and reduce potential hazards of the process.  All recommendations have been scheduled for completion and implementation responsibility has been assigned for each action item (see PHA Update and Revalidation Report dated June 1, 2013.



Representative planned changes to improve safety include:



1.    Minor changes to the Standard Operating Procedures

2.    Minor to moderate equipment change considerations

3.    Minor maintenance revisions

4.    Evaluation of valve accessibility
